required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: iFR Guided Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting
clinical_study.official_title: The Impact of Pre-Operative iFR Measurements on Post-Operative Graft Patency in Patients Undergoing Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting Surgery

brief_summary.textblock:
The expected outcome of better and improved patency of bypass grafts and its direct relation to pre-operative iFR measurements of stenosis as compared to direct visual physiology of stenosis in the coronary angiogram.
To establish the correlation between the use of intracoronary physiology and improved graft patency at 12 months for patients undergoing CABG surgery.
It is 100 patients single-centre feasibility study

detailed_description.textblock:
Patients suffering from coronary artery disease undergo coronary artery bypass grafting surgery (CABG) as the standard of care. The selection of which vessels to bypass is usually at the discretion of the surgeon forming an opinion based on the pre-operative angiographic imaging. Intra-coronary physiology (iFR measurements) is more accurate to determine the level of damage to the coronary arteries; however, currently it is not used for CABG pre-assessment, but only for percutaneous intervention also known as stenting as it has been shown to improve outcomes. Although, the use of intracoronary physiology has not been extensively studied or validated in patients undergoing CABG.
Patients with multi-vessel coronary artery disease (CAD) who are planned for surgical revascularization with coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), will have iFR measurement taken during invasive coronary angiography as part of standard care, they will undergo CABG and will have echocardiography at 3 and 12 months and computed tomography coronary angiography (CTCA) at 12 months.
Early graft failure will be assessed by the presentation of any clinical symptoms, major adverse cardiovascular and cerebrovascular events (MACCE) and echocardiography at 3 and 12 months. The endpoint will be graft patency as assessed by CT coronary angiography at 12 months.
Anticipated recruitment is 12-13 months. Follow-up with echocardiography at 3 and 12 months and a CTCA at 12 months. Quality of Life questionnaire will be completed by the patient at 3 months during the follow-up appointment.
Patients will continue on optimal medical therapy. Clinic visit and quality of life scale questionnaires will be recorded at 3 and 12 months and echocardiography will be assessed at 3 and 12 months. Graft patency at 12 months will be assessed with a CT coronary angiography.

primary_outcome.description: The primary endpoint will be graft patency as assessed by CT coronary angiography at 12 months.

secondary_outcome.description: Assessed by presentation of clinical symptoms, blood tests (Troponin levels) and echocardiography during follow-up visit at 3 and 12 months or anytime within 12 months.

Assessed by presentation of clinical symptoms, blood tests (Troponin levels), echocardiography during follow-up visit at 3 and 12 months or anytime within 12 months and in addition, evidence of percutaneous or surgical revascularisation within the last 12 months.
Assessed by presentation of clinical symptoms during follow-up visit at 3 and 12 months or anytime within 12 months

arm_group.arm_group_label: Patients with multi-vessel coronary artery disease (MVCAD)
arm_group.description: iFR measurements will be taken pre-operatively during the invasive coronary angiography.

intervention.description: Patients with MVCAD will undergo CABG as per standard of care.
intervention.arm_group_label: Patients with multi-vessel coronary artery disease (MVCAD)

study_pop.textblock: 100 patients single-centre feasibility study. Patients with confirmed MVCAD undergoing CABG as per standard of care will be recruited.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion criteria
- Age of 25 to 80 years of age
- Willing to participate and able to understand, read and sign the informed consent document before the planned procedure
- Eligible for coronary angiography and CABG
- CAD in two or more native major epicardial vessels or their branches by coronary angiogram with visually assessed de novo coronary stenosis
- Stable angina
- Plan for CABG as optimal revascularization mode as decided by the treating clinical team
Exclusion criteria
- Ejection Fractionâ‰¤ 40%
- History of Atrial fibrillation /flutter
- History of MI within last30 days
- Emergency CABG
- Severe Valvular heart disease
- Haemodynamic instability at the time of angiography
- Contraindications to CABG
- Significant hepatic or lung disease (chronic pulmonary obstructive disease), and/or malignant disease with an unfavourable prognosis that may influence survival within the next 5 years.
- Pregnancy
- STEMI within 48 hours of the procedure

facility.name: Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust - Hammersmith Hospital

investigator.last_name: Sayan Sen, BSc, MBBS, MRCP, PhD, MRCP

patient_data.ipd_description: Anonymised individual participant data for all primary and secondary outcome measures will be made available.
